<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Seismic_wave skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Seismic wave</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Earthquakes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Earthquakes (page does not exist)">Template:Earthquakes</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pswaves.jpg" title="File:Pswaves.jpg">File:Pswaves.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Body waves and surface waves</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Seismogram.gif" title="File:Seismogram.gif">File:Seismogram.gif</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">p-wave and s-wave from seismograph</div></div></div>
<p><b>Seismic waves</b> are waves of energy that travel through the Earth's layers, and are a result of an <a href="/wiki/Earthquake" title="Earthquake">earthquake</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Explosion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Explosion (page does not exist)">explosion</a>, or a volcano that imparts low-frequency acoustic energy. Many other natural and anthropogenic sources create low amplitude waves commonly referred to as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ambient_Vibrations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ambient Vibrations (page does not exist)">ambient vibrations</a>. Seismic waves are studied by <a href="/wiki/Geophysics" title="Geophysics">geophysicists</a> called <a href="/wiki/Seismology" title="Seismology">seismologists</a>. Seismic wave fields are recorded by a <a href="/wiki/Seismometer" title="Seismometer">seismometer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hydrophone" title="Hydrophone">hydrophone</a> (in water), or <a href="/wiki/Accelerometer" title="Accelerometer">accelerometer</a>.
</p><p>The propagation <a href="/w/index.php?title=Signal_velocity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Signal velocity (page does not exist)">velocity</a> of the waves depends on <a href="/wiki/Density" title="Density">density</a> and <a href="/wiki/Elasticity_(physics)" title="Elasticity (physics)">elasticity</a> of the medium. Velocity tends to increase with depth, and ranges from approximately 2 to 8&#160;km/s in the Earth's <a href="/wiki/Crust_(geology)" title="Crust (geology)">crust</a> up to 13&#160;km/s in the deep <a href="/wiki/Mantle_(geology)" title="Mantle (geology)">mantle</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
</p><p>Earthquakes create various types of waves with different velocities; when reaching seismic observatories, their different <a href="/w/index.php?title=Propagation_speed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Propagation speed (page does not exist)">travel time</a> help scientists to locate the source of the earthquake <a href="/wiki/Hypocenter" title="Hypocenter">hypocenter</a>. In geophysics the refraction or reflection of seismic waves is used for research into the structure of the Earth's interior, and man made vibrations are often generated to investigate shallow, subsurface structures.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Types_of_seismic_waves"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Types of seismic waves</span></a>
<ul>

<ul>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-3"><a href="#Primary_waves"><span class="tocnumber">1.1.1</span> <span class="toctext">Primary waves</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-4"><a href="#Secondary_waves"><span class="tocnumber">1.1.2</span> <span class="toctext">Secondary waves</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#Surface_waves"><span class="tocnumber">1.2</span> <span class="toctext">Surface waves</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-6"><a href="#Rayleigh_waves"><span class="tocnumber">1.2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Rayleigh waves</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-7"><a href="#Love_waves"><span class="tocnumber">1.2.2</span> <span class="toctext">Love waves</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-8"><a href="#Stoneley_waves"><span class="tocnumber">1.2.3</span> <span class="toctext">Stoneley waves</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-9"><a href="#Free_oscillations_of_the_Earth"><span class="tocnumber">1.2.4</span> <span class="toctext">Free oscillations of the Earth</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-10"><a href="#P_and_S_waves_in_Earth.27s_mantle_and_core"><span class="tocnumber">1.3</span> <span class="toctext">P and S waves in Earth's mantle and core</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-11"><a href="#Notation"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Notation</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-12"><a href="#Usefulness_of_P_and_S_waves_in_locating_an_event"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Usefulness of P and S waves in locating an event</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-13"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-14"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-15"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Types_of_seismic_waves">Types of seismic waves</span></h2>
<p>Among the many types of seismic waves, one can make a broad distinction between <i>body waves</i> and <i>surface waves</i>.
</p>
<ul>
<li> Body waves travel through the interior of the Earth, surface waves travel across the surface 
</li>
<li> Surface waves decay more slowly with distance than do body waves, which travel in three dimensions 
</li>
<li> Particle motion of surface waves is larger than that of body waves, so surface waves tend to cause more damage
</li>
</ul>
<p>Other modes of wave propagation exist than those described in this article; though of comparatively minor importance for earth-borne waves, they are important in the case of <a href="/wiki/Asteroseismology" title="Asteroseismology">asteroseismology</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Body_waves">Body waves</span></h3>
<p>Body waves travel through the interior of the Earth. They create <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raypath&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raypath (page does not exist)">raypaths</a> refracted by the varying <a href="/wiki/Density" title="Density">density</a> and <a href="/wiki/Young%27s_modulus" title="Young's modulus">modulus</a> (stiffness) of the Earth's interior.  The density and modulus, in turn, vary according to temperature, composition, and phase.  This effect resembles the <a href="/wiki/Refraction" title="Refraction">refraction</a> of <a href="/wiki/Light_wave" title="Light wave" class="mw-redirect">light waves</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Primary_waves">Primary waves</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Primary waves (P-waves) are compressional waves that are <a href="/wiki/Longitudinal_wave" title="Longitudinal wave">longitudinal</a> in nature.  P waves are pressure waves that travel faster than other waves through the earth to arrive at seismograph stations first, hence the name "Primary". These waves can travel through any type of material, including fluids, and can travel at nearly twice the speed of S waves. In air, they take the form of sound waves, hence they travel at the <a href="/wiki/Speed_of_sound" title="Speed of sound">speed of sound</a>. Typical speeds are 330&#160;m/s in air, 1450&#160;m/s in water and about 5000&#160;m/s in <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">granite</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Secondary_waves">Secondary waves</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Secondary waves (S-waves) are shear waves that are <a href="/wiki/Transverse_wave" title="Transverse wave">transverse</a> in nature. Following an earthquake event, S-waves arrive at seismograph stations after the faster-moving P-waves and displace the ground perpendicular to the direction of propagation. Depending on the propagational direction, the wave can take on different surface characteristics; for example, in the case of horizontally polarized S waves, the ground moves alternately to one side and then the other. S-waves can travel only through solids, as fluids (liquids and gases) do not support shear stresses. S-waves are slower than P-waves, and speeds are typically around 60% of that of P-waves in any given material.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Surface_waves">Surface waves</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Seismic surface waves travel along the Earth's surface. They are called surface waves because they diminish as they get further from the surface. Their velocity is lower than the velocity of the seismic body waves (P and S). Because of the long duration and large amplitude of the surface waves, they can be the most destructive type of seismic wave. Surface waves travel more slowly than the other type of seismic waves.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Rayleigh_waves">Rayleigh waves</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a> 
Rayleigh waves, also called ground roll, are surface waves that travel as ripples with motions that are similar to those of waves on the surface of water (note, however, that the associated particle motion at shallow depths is retrograde, and that the restoring force in Rayleigh and in other seismic waves is elastic, not gravitational as for water waves). The existence of these waves was predicted by John William Strutt, <a href="/wiki/Lord_Rayleigh" title="Lord Rayleigh" class="mw-redirect">Lord Rayleigh</a>, in 1885. They are slower than body waves, roughly 90% of the velocity of S waves for typical homogeneous elastic media. In the layered medium (like the crust and upper mantle) the velocity of the Rayleigh waves depends on their frequency and wavelength. See also <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lamb_waves&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lamb waves (page does not exist)">Lamb waves</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Love_waves">Love waves</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Love waves are horizontally <a href="/wiki/Polarization_(waves)" title="Polarization (waves)">polarized</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shear_wave&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shear wave (page does not exist)">shear waves</a> (SH waves), existing only in the presence of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Semi-infinite&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Semi-infinite (page does not exist)">semi-infinite</a> medium overlain by an upper layer of finite thickness.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>  They are named after <a href="/wiki/A.E.H._Love" title="A.E.H. Love" class="mw-redirect">A.E.H. Love</a>, a British mathematician who created a mathematical model of the waves in 1911.  They usually travel slightly faster than Rayleigh waves, about 90% of the S wave velocity, and have the largest amplitude.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Stoneley_waves">Stoneley waves</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
A Stoneley wave is a type of large amplitude Rayleigh wave that propagates along a solid-fluid boundary or under specific conditions also along solid-solid boundary. They can be generated along the walls of a fluid-filled <a href="/wiki/Borehole" title="Borehole">borehole</a>, being an important source of coherent noise in <a href="/wiki/Vertical_seismic_profile" title="Vertical seismic profile">VSPs</a> and making up the low frequency component of the source in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sonic_logging&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sonic logging (page does not exist)">sonic logging</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
The equation for Stoneley waves was first given by Dr. Robert Stoneley (1894 - 1976), Emeritus Professor of Seismology, Cambridge.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Free_oscillations_of_the_Earth">Free oscillations of the Earth</span></h4>
<p>This phenomenon is a result of interference between two surface waves traveling in opposite directions. In fact it is a surface <a href="/wiki/Standing_wave" title="Standing wave">standing wave</a>. Interference of Rayleigh waves results in <i>spheroidal oscillation S</i> while interference of Love waves gives <i>toroidal oscillation T</i>. The modes of oscillations are specified by three numbers, e.g.  <sub>n</sub>S<sub>l</sub><sup>m</sup>, where <i>l</i> is the angular order number (or <i>spherical harmonic degree</i>, see <a href="/wiki/Spherical_harmonics" title="Spherical harmonics">Spherical harmonics</a> for more details). The number <i>m</i> is the azimuthal order number. It may take on 2<i>l</i>+1 values from -<i>l</i> to +<i>l</i>. The number <i>n</i> is the <i>radial order number</i>. It means the wave with <i>n</i> zero crossings in radius. The fundamental spheroidal mode <sub>0</sub>S<sub>2</sub> has a period of about 54 minutes. The period of <sub>0</sub>S<sub>3</sub> is 36 minutes, and <sub>0</sub>S<sub>4</sub> is 26 minutes. 
Two modes cannot naturally exist are the <sub>0</sub>S<sub>0</sub> and <sub>0</sub>T<sub>1</sub>. The spheroidal mode <sub>0</sub>S<sub>0</sub> doesn't exist because it requires a change in the center of gravity, which can't happen. The toroidal mode <sub>0</sub>T<sub>1</sub> doesn't exist because it requires the entire sphere to twist, which violates the <a href="/wiki/Conservation_of_angular_momentum" title="Conservation of angular momentum" class="mw-redirect">conservation of angular momentum</a>.
The fundamental toroidal mode <sub>0</sub>T<sub>2</sub> has a period of about 44 minutes <sup>[1]</sup>. For spherically symmetric Earth the period for given <i>n</i> and <i>l</i> does not depend on <i>m</i>. The first observations of free oscillations of the Earth were done during the great 1960 earthquake in Chile. Presently periods of thousands modes are known. These data are used for determining some large scale structures of the Earth interior.       
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fundametal_toroidal_oscillation_Earth.gif" title="File:Fundametal toroidal oscillation Earth.gif">File:Fundametal toroidal oscillation Earth.gif</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The sense of motion for toroidal <sub>0</sub>T<sub>1</sub> oscillation for two moments of time.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fundamental_spheroidal_oscillation_Earth.gif" title="File:Fundamental spheroidal oscillation Earth.gif">File:Fundamental spheroidal oscillation Earth.gif</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The scheme of motion for spheroidal <sub>0</sub>S<sub>2</sub> oscillation.Dashed lines give nodal (zero) lines. Arrows give the sense of motion.</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="P_and_S_waves_in_Earth.27s_mantle_and_core">P and S waves in Earth's mantle and core</span></h3>
<p>An earthquake occurs, seismographs near the <a href="/wiki/Epicenter" title="Epicenter">epicenter</a> are able to record both P and S waves, but those at a greater distance no longer detect the high frequencies of the first S wave.  Since shear waves cannot pass through liquids, this phenomenon was original evidence for the now well-established observation that the Earth has a liquid <a href="/wiki/Outer_core" title="Outer core">outer core</a>, as demonstrated by <a href="/wiki/Richard_Dixon_Oldham" title="Richard Dixon Oldham">Richard Dixon Oldham</a>.  This kind of observation has also been used to argue, by seismic testing, that the <a href="/wiki/Moon" title="Moon">Moon</a> has a solid core, although recent geodetic studies suggest the core is still molten{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notation">Notation</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Earthquake_wave_paths.svg" title="File:Earthquake wave paths.svg">File:Earthquake wave paths.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Earthquake wave paths</div></div></div>
<p>The path that a wave takes between the focus and the observation point is often drawn as a ray diagram.  An example of this is shown in a figure above.  When reflections are taken into account there are an infinite number of paths that a wave can take.  Each path is denoted by a set of letters that describe the trajectory and phase through the Earth.  In general an upper case denotes a transmitted wave and a lower case denotes a reflected wave.  The two exceptions to this seem to be "g" and "n".  The notation is taken from <sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> and.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tr>
<td> c </td>
<td> the wave reflects off the outer core
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> d </td>
<td> a wave that has been reflected off a discontinuity at depth d
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> g </td>
<td> a wave that only travels through the crust
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> i </td>
<td> a wave that reflects off the inner core
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> I </td>
<td> a P-wave in the inner core
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> h </td>
<td> a reflection off a discontinuity in the inner core
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> J </td>
<td> an S wave in the inner core
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> K </td>
<td> a P-wave in the outer core
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> L </td>
<td> a Love wave sometimes called LT-Wave (Both caps, while an Lt is different)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> n </td>
<td> a wave that travels along the boundary between the crust and mantle
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> P </td>
<td> a P wave in the mantle
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> p </td>
<td> a P wave ascending to the surface from the focus
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> R </td>
<td> a Rayleigh wave
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> S </td>
<td> an S wave in the mantle
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> s </td>
<td> an S wave ascending to the surface from the focus
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> w </td>
<td> the wave reflects off the bottom of the ocean
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> </td>
<td> No letter is used when the wave reflects off of the surface
</td></tr></table>
<p>For example:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <b>ScP</b> is a wave that begins traveling towards the center of the Earth as an S wave.  Upon reaching the outer core the wave reflects as a P wave.
</li>
<li> <b>sPKIKP</b> is a wave path that begins traveling towards the surface as an S-wave.  At the surface it reflects as a P-wave. The P-wave then travels through the outer core, the inner core, the outer core, and the mantle.
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Usefulness_of_P_and_S_waves_in_locating_an_event">Usefulness of P and S waves in locating an event</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hypocenter_Calculation.png" title="File:Hypocenter Calculation.png">File:Hypocenter Calculation.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Hypocenter/Epicenter of an earthquake is calculated by using the seismic data of that earthquake from at least three different locations.</div></div></div>
<p>In the case of local or nearby earthquakes, the difference in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arrival_time&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arrival time (page does not exist)">arrival times</a> of the P and S waves can be used to determine the distance to the event. In the case of earthquakes that have occurred at global distances, three or more geographically diverse observing stations (using a common <a href="/wiki/Clock" title="Clock">clock</a>) recording P-wave arrivals permits the computation of a unique time and location on the planet for the event. Typically, dozens or even hundreds of P-wave arrivals are used to calculate <a href="/wiki/Hypocenter" title="Hypocenter">hypocenters</a>. The misfit generated by a hypocenter calculation is known as "the residual". Residuals of 0.5 second or less are typical for distant events, residuals of 0.1-0.2 s typical for local events, meaning most reported P arrivals fit the computed hypocenter that well. Typically a location program will start by assuming the event occurred at a depth of about 33&#160;km; then it minimizes the residual by adjusting depth. Most events occur at depths shallower than about 40&#160;km, but some occur as deep as 700&#160;km.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ondes_P_et_S_1d_30_petit.gif" title="File:Ondes P et S 1d 30 petit.gif">File:Ondes P et S 1d 30 petit.gif</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">P- and S-waves sharing with the propagation</div></div></div>
<p>A quick way to determine the distance from a location to the origin of a seismic wave less than 200&#160;km away is to take the difference in arrival time of the P wave and the S wave in <a href="/wiki/Second" title="Second">seconds</a> and multiply by 8&#160;kilometers per second.  Modern seismic arrays use more complicated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Earthquake_location&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Earthquake location (page does not exist)">earthquake location</a> techniques.
</p><p>At teleseismic distances, the first arriving P waves have necessarily travelled deep into the mantle, and perhaps have even refracted into the outer core of the planet, before travelling back up to the Earth's surface where the seismographic stations are located. The waves travel more quickly than if they had traveled in a straight line from the earthquake.  This is due to the appreciably increased <a href="/wiki/Speed_of_sound#Three-dimensional_solids" title="Speed of sound">velocities</a> within the planet, and is termed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Huygens%27_Principle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Huygens' Principle (page does not exist)">Huygens' Principle</a>. <a href="/wiki/Density" title="Density">Density</a> in the planet increases with depth, which would slow the waves, but the <a href="/wiki/Young%27s_modulus" title="Young's modulus">modulus</a> of the rock increases much more, so deeper means faster. Therefore, a longer route can take a shorter time.
</p><p>The travel time must be calculated very accurately in order to compute a precise hypocenter. Since P waves move at many kilometers per second, being off on travel-time calculation by even a half second can mean an error of many kilometers in terms of distance.  In practice, P arrivals from many stations are used and the errors cancel out, so the computed epicenter is likely to be quite accurate, on the order of 10–50&#160;km or so around the world.  Dense arrays of nearby sensors such as those that exist in California can provide accuracy of roughly a kilometer, and much greater accuracy is possible when timing is measured directly by <a href="/wiki/Cross-correlation" title="Cross-correlation">cross-correlation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Seismogram" title="Seismogram">seismogram</a> waveforms.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adams%E2%80%93Williamson_equation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adams–Williamson equation (page does not exist)">Adams–Williamson equation</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Reflection_seismology" title="Reflection seismology">Reflection seismology</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Earthquakes" title="Earthquakes" class="mw-redirect">earthquakes</a>
</li>
</ul>
